Dear Yulonda Shell:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Sincerely,
Vivian D Malleck, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction, prevention;
Title prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
1

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159
Section (5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
Description manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity
of the youth’s behavior, chronological and developmental age,
size, gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma,
and must be done in a manner consistent with the youth’s
treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 12/07/2024, a youth refused to leave the medication line. A
staff member picked the youth up and threw the youth to the
ground. The youth sustained a rug burn.
Investigation Interviews
Complainant was interviewed on 12/12/2024. Complainant did
not have additional information.
Youth A was interviewed on 12/17/2024 at Vista Specialty with
another Division of Child Welfare Licensing (DCWL) consultant.
Youth A stated Supervisor and Staff 1 tried to grab her arms in the
administrative wing and push her towards her wing because Youth
A wanted to fight a youth on another wing. Youth A stated
Program Manager came to the administrative wing, picked her up
(feet off the ground) and carried her to the common area where he
threw her to the ground. Youth A stated she accidentally kicked
Supervisor when she got up from the ground and stood in the
corner with Program Manager. Youth A stated Supervisor and
Program Manager tried to physically manage her. Youth A stated
Program Manager twisted Youth A’s right arm behind her back
and bent her right thumb. Youth A stated Program Manager
released his hold and Youth A walked away from the corner,
picked up couch cushions and threw them at Program Manager.
Youth A stated after throwing couch cushions she went back to D-
wing on her own. Youth A stated she did not recall additional
details and if other staff were involved in this incident. Youth A
stated she did not recall what prompted her to return to D-wing.
Youth A’s right thumb was observed without swelling and bruising
and without pain when flexed. Youth A stated the abrasion on her
right knee healed. Youth A was observed with a light brown mark
on her right knee approximately 1 inch long and ½ inch wide. The
mark viewed was without scabbing or broken skin. Youth A stated
she was unsure if she saw a nurse after this incident.
2

Youth A’s worker was interviewed by phone on 12/12/2024.
Youth A’s worker stated she met with Youth A on 12/11/2024 and
did not observe marks or injury on Youth A.
Supervisor was interviewed on 12/17/2024 at Vista Specialty with
another Department of Health and Human Service (DHHS)
worker, DCWL consultant and Vista Representative. Supervisor
stated she dispensed medication to Youth A in the administrative
hallway and Youth A refused to return to D-wing afterwards
because she wanted to antagonize a youth on another wing.
Supervisor stated she and Staff 1 attempted a two person hold to
escort Youth A back to D-wing but called for assistance when
Youth A refused to cooperate. Supervisor stated Program
Manager came to the administrative hallway, picked up Youth A
and took her to D-wing’s common area. Supervisor stated Youth A
went to the ground on her knees when Program Manager
released her. Supervisor stated Youth A kicked and swung at
Supervisor and Program Manager when she got up and was
pushed into the corner by Program Manager. Supervisor stated
Program Manager held Youth A’s hands and Youth A held onto
Program Manager’s beard. Supervisor stated Staff 2 arrived to
assist and Youth A began to kick at Staff 2. Supervisor stated
Youth A walked away from the corner and picked up couch
cushions and threw them. Supervisor stated Program Manager
verbally redirected Youth A and asked what she needed.
Supervisor stated she left the common area to respond to an
assistance call on C-wing. Supervisor stated when she returned to
the common area Youth A was calmer and returned to D-wing on
her own without incident. Supervisor stated Youth A did not
complain of injury. Supervisor stated Program Manager did not
use Crisis Prevention Institute techniques when he kept Youth A
in the corner.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 12/17/2024 at Vista Specialty with
another DHHS worker, DCWL consultant and Vista
Representative. Staff 1 stated Youth A refused verbal direction to
return to D-wing after taking her medication because she wanted
to antagonize a youth on another wing. Staff 1 stated Youth A
tried to push past Staff 1 and Supervisor and said, “Let me go to
the other side. Fuck this bitch.” Staff 1 stated she called for
assistance and Program Manager responded. Staff 1 stated
Program Manager grabbed Youth A by her arms, picked her up
and took her to the common area when she did not comply with
verbal redirection to go back to D-wing. Staff 1 stated she left the
common area and returned to C-wing. Staff 1 stated she did not
witness Youth A fall down in this incident.
3

Staff 2 was interviewed on 12/20/2024 by phone. Staff 2 stated he
responded to an assistance call about Youth A in the common
area. Staff 2 stated Program Manager held Youth A’s hand and
kept her in a corner in the common area because Youth A wanted
to harm a youth on another wing. Staff 2 stated Youth A tried to hit
Program Manager and Supervisor while she was in the corner.
Staff 2 stated Youth A lost her balance and went down to the
ground when she tried to punch Program Manager. Staff 2 stated
Youth A got up and started spitting at Program Manager. Staff 2
stated Youth A walked away from the corner, picked up couch
cushions and threw them at Program Manager. Staff 2 stated he
verbally redirected Youth A to sit down in the common area or
return to D-wing for bed. Staff 2 stated he and Program Manager
verbally redirected and watched Youth A throw couch cushions to
give her space to vent. Staff 2 stated Youth A returned to D-wing
without incident and apologized for her behaviors the next day.
Staff 2 stated Youth A was not physically managed in this incident.
Program Manager was interviewed on 12/17/2024 at Vista
Specialty with another DHHS worker, DCWL consultant and Vista
Representative. Program Manager stated Youth A received her
medication from Supervisor on the administrative wing and
wanted to go to another wing to antagonize a youth instead of
returning to D-wing. Program Manager stated Supervisor 1 and
Staff 1 tried to verbally and physically redirect Youth A from
leaving the administrative wing when he arrived. Program
Manager stated he wrapped his arms around Youth A from behind
her and moved Youth A with her feet on the ground to the end of
the hallway towards D-wing. Program Manager stated he let go of
Youth A after passing through the door to the common area.
Program Manager stated Youth A fell down on her knees or side
and got up kicking at him, Supervisor and at Staff 2 when he
arrived. Program Manager stated he held one of Youth A’s hand
as she grabbed his beard. Program Manager stated he let Youth
A leave the corner and Youth A walked to the couch and threw a
couch cushion multiple times. Program Manager stated he and
Staff 2 blocked the couch cushion from hitting them while Youth A
said, “I don’t need y’all. I don’t need to be here.” Program
Manager stated Youth A settled down on her own and returned to
D-wing without issue. Program Manager stated Supervisor called
for a nursing assessment and Youth A was seen. Program
Manager stated Supervisor left the common area earlier in this
incident when assistance was called on another wing.
Video
4

12/07/2024 video does not have sound. At 9:06 PM female staff
(Supervisor 1 and Staff 1) stand on each side of Youth A trying to
place her in a standing two person hold in the administrative
hallway by the medication room. Youth A resists and stands with
her back to the wall. Program Manager arrives, wraps his arms
around Youth A’s upper body, when she steps away from the wall,
and carries her down the hallway to the common area. Program
Manager releases Youth A and Youth A falls forward on to the
ground on her knees. (Youth A is wearing long pajama pants.)
Youth A gets up and flails her arms at Program Manager. Program
Manager holds Youth A’s wrists and maneuvers Youth A in a
pushing manner to the nearest corner. Program Manager keeps
Youth A in the corner with his hip and backside to Youth A.
Supervisor stands near the corner watching. Staff 2 arrives and
stands by Program Manager and Supervisor. Program Manager,
Supervisor and Staff 2’s backsides block the camera from
capturing what is occurring with Youth A. It appears Staff 2 and
Supervisor may be assisting Program Manager with Youth A in
the corner. Youth A is released and walks away from the corner,
bangs on a door and pushes Staff 2. Youth A walks around the
common area and pushes Program Manager. Youth A picks up
and tosses a couch cushion at Program Manager. Program
Manager deflects the couch cushion and places it back on the
couch. Youth A walks around the common area as Program
Manager and Staff 2 follow. Supervisor leaves the common area.
Youth A continues to walk around and periodically pick up a couch
cushion and toss it at Program Manager, who blocks the cushion.
Supervisor returns and leaves the common area. Youth A leaves
the common area on her own with Program Manager and Staff 2
following at 9:18 PM.
Documentation
Supervisor wrote an incident report dated 12/07/2024. Incident
report matches the sequence of events in her interview.
Vista Representative stated Youth A does not have a nurse’s note
stating she was checked for injuries on 12/07/2024.
Staff 2 completed Crisis Prevention Institute’s Non-violent
Physical Crisis Intervention training on 11/20/2024 and
11/21/2024. Staff 2 does not have a discipline history.
Supervisor completed Crisis Prevention Institute’s Non-violent
Physical Crisis Intervention training on 07/15/2024 and
07/16/2024. Supervisor does not have a discipline history.
5

Program Manager completed Crisis Prevention Institute’s Non-
violent Physical Crisis Intervention training for trainers on
02/19/2023, 02/21/2023, 02/22/2023 and 02/23/2023. Program
Manager’s training documentation states train the trainer
certification is good for two years. Program Manager does not
have discipline history related to physical management.
Crisis Prevention Institute (CPI) training materials were reviewed
and it was found that CPI does not teach a wrap-around hold that
involves physically moving a youth with their feet on or off the
ground to another location. It also does not teach a one person
hold that involves holding a youth’s hand and using one’s body to
block the youth from leaving a corner.
Tour
The administrative hallway leads to D-wing’s common area and
separated by a door. Upon entering the common area, C-wing is
located to the left and separated by a door. Across from the
administrative wing door is D-wing’s door. The common area has
three couches with removable cushions.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance when Program Manager
wrapped his arms around Youth A, picked her up and carried her
down the administrative hallway to the common area. Program
Manager also used his body as a barricade to keep Youth A in a
corner in the common area. These methods are not taught in
Crisis Prevention Institute - Nonviolent Crisis Prevention
Intervention.
It cannot be definitively determined how Youth A obtained the
mark on her right knee.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
Staff must complete refresher training annually or more frequently
as needed. A certified physical management trainer for Crisis
Prevention Institute is valid for two years. The trainer is to attend a
yearly training as a staff participant in the year they are not
recertified as a trainer.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Rule Code R 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Title prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
6

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159
Section (1)A child caring institution, including private secure juvenile
Description justice facilities, shall establish a process improvement and
restraint reduction/elimination plan that: (a) Includes
documentation of each restraint.
Violation Additional Finding
Type
Investigation Documentation
Supervisor wrote an incident report dated 12/07/2024. Incident
report does not mark physical management occurred. “No” is
entered in the physical management prompt box.
Child Care Institution R 400.4101 Definitions states:
(1) As used in these rules: (v) “Personal restraint” means the
application of physical force, without the use of a device, that
restricts the free movement of a youth’s body. Personal restraint
does not include: (i) The use of a protective or adaptive device. (ii)
Briefly holding a minor child without undue force in order to calm
or comfort him or her. (iii) Holding a minor child's hand, wrist,
shoulder, or arm to safely escort him or her from 1 area to
another. (iv) The use of a protective or adaptive device or a device
primarily intended to provide anatomical support.
Vista Representative stated Youth A does not have a nurse’s note
indicating she was checked for injuries on 12/07/2024 following
her incident with Staff 1, Supervisor 1, Program Manager and
Staff 2.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance when Supervisor did not
identify and mark on the incident report that physical management
occurred when Supervisor and Staff 1 tried to place Youth A in a
two person hold and Program Manager’s physical contact with
Youth A in the administrative hallway and common area to control
her movement. (Please see CCI Rule 400.4159 (5) in this report
for interview information.)
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The result of not identifying and documenting Youth A’s physical
management on the incident report resulted in the agency’s failure
to generate a MiSACWIS restraint report as required by
R 400.4163 Health status assessment; notification; debriefing;
reporting. (5) An agency will provide an incident report on a form
prescribed by the department for each incident involving the use
of seclusion or restraint. The initial report shall be submitted to the
department within 24 hours of the incident occurring. A final
7

incident report shall be submitted no later than 72 hours after the
incident has occurred. This was not cited as it stems from R
400.4159 (1) citation in this investigation. Those responsible for
reviewing and approving the incident report must seek clarification
when needed and review for accuracy prior to approval of incident
report to ensure MiSACWIS documentation.
The result of not identifying Youth A’s physical management
resulted in the agency’s failure for Youth A being assessed by
health services following physical management as required by
R 400.4163 Health status assessment; notification; debriefing;
reporting. Rule 163. (2) Health status screening of the youth will
occur immediately after seclusion or restraint by staff assigned to
this screening, as defined in agency policy. If the youth has any
physical complaints or if the screening staff has any concerns,
depending on the severity of the complaint or concerns, the staff
will arrange for the youth’s health needs to be met immediately by
any of the following actions: (a) Consultation with the on-call or
onsite nursing staff. (b) Referral for an off-site health assessment.
(c) Contacting emergency medical services. This was not cited as
it stems from this R 400.4159 (1) citation in this investigation.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
